body_text.text: The purification steps contained 20 mM nicotinamide to inhibit deacetylation. The final buffer conditions of CypAAcK were 50 mM K 2 HPO 4 /KH 2 PO 4 pH 6.4, 100 mM NaCl, 2 mM βmercaptoethanol (buffer A). HIV1 and HIV2 N-terminal capsid proteins were expressed in E. coli and precipitated by addition of ammonium sulfate to a final concentration of 20% (w/v) essentially as described 1 . Following resuspension and dialysis the proteins were purified by SP ion-exchange and size exclusion.
All measurements were carried out in buffer A (see above
Data were indexed and integrated using MOSFLM and scaled in SCALA 3 . Initial phases were determined with the program Phaser 4 using the CypA structure (PDB: 2CPL 5 ) as a template.
The phases for the HIV1-CA N :CypAAcK-compex were obtained using the HIV1-CA

BIBREF0.title: Molecular recognition in the HIV-1 capsid/cyclophilin A complex

BIBREF1.title: Cyclophilin and peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase are probably identical proteins

BIBREF4.title: Similarities and differences between human cyclophilin A and other beta-barrel structures. Structural refinement at 1.63 A resolution

BIBREF5.title: Crystal structure of human cyclophilin A bound to the amino-terminal domain of HIV-1 capsid

BIBREF6.title: X-ray structure of a monomeric cyclophilin A-cyclosporin A crystal complex at 2.1 A resolution

BIBREF7.title: Coot: model-building tools for molecular graphics

BIBREF8.title: Efficient anisotropic refinement of macromolecular structures using FFT

FIGREF0.text: and for the CypAAcK:Cs the CypA:Cs-complex (PDB: 1CWA 7 ) was used. The program Coot 8 was used for model building, REFMAC 9 for refinement. All structure figures were prepared with PyMOL 10 . Data collection and refinement statistics are given in Supplementary Table 2. Examples of electron density for each determined structure have been submitted as Supplementary Figure 6. Immunodepletion experiments For standardization experiments, 100 ng of different ratios of Cyp:CypAcK (40:60, 60:40, 80:20, 100:0) were incubated with 1 µg of anti-acetyl-lysine antibody and incubated at 4°C for 1 h. For depletion 25 µl of protein-A-sepharose was added. The supernatant was analysed by SDS-Page and western-blotting using anti-CypA antibody.Calcineurin-Phosphatase-AssayThe assay was performed in a microtitre format, with a final concentration Cyp;Cs range from12 µM to 187.5 nM. Assay buffer contained 100 mM Tris/HCl pH 7.5, 200 mM NaCl, 12 mM MgCl 2 , 1mM DTT, 0.05% NP-40 and 1 mM CaCl 2 . The protein buffer was phosphate free and contained 20 mM HEPES pH 6.4, 100 mM NaCl, 2 mM β-mercaptoethanol. After addition of 25 ml of calmodulin (final concentration 25 nM), and 5 ml calcineurin-Phosphatase (final concentration 0.8 U/ml) the reactions were equilibrated to 37°C for 10 min. The reaction was started by addition of RII-phosphopeptide (0.15 mM) incubated at 37°C for 90 min and stopped by addition of 100 ml of malachit green solution. After incubation for 30 min the A 620 nm was read on a microplate reader (Tecan, Safire). The inhibitory dissociation constant K i was determined using increasing concentrations of the CypA:Cs complex, plotting the obtained absorption values against those and fitting a quadratic equation to the data Homogenous and site-specific incorporation of acetyllysine into CypA. (a&b) CypA can be immunoprecipitated from HeLa and Jurkat T cells (a) and the acetylated fraction detected by anti-acetyllysine antibody in both cell types (b). Recombinant CypA and CypAAcK are present as controls. (c) Quantification of acetylated CypA in HeLa and Jurkat cells using an immunodepletion approach. Endogenous CypA from cell lysate is depleted with anti-acetyllysine antibody and compared to nondepleted material by western blot with an anti-CypA-antibody. These results show that a substantial proportion of CypA is acetylated in both HeLa and Jurkat cells. Supplementary Figure 2: Standardization of acetyated CypA immunodepletion using recombinant proteins. 100 ng of different ratios of Cyp:CypAcK (40:60, 60:40, 80:20, 100:0) were incubated with 1 µg of anti-acetyl-lysine antibody and incubated at 4°C for 1 h. For depletion 25 µl of protein-A-sepharose was added. The supernatant was analysed by SDS-PAGE and western-blotting using an anti-CypA antibody. The resulting western blot is shown together with a plot of the measured intensity of each band. The intensities represent mean values of three measurements ± s.d. Application of this standardization gives acetylated CypA levels in HeLa of 50 ± 5% and in Jurkat cells of 38 ± 3%. Production of recombinant acetylated CypA (a) Analysis of CypA acetylation by western blot (500 ng of CypA/CypAAcK per lane). The recombinantly expressed CypAAcK is detected with both an anti-CypA antibody and an anti-acetyllysine antibody. (b) Molecular mass determination of CypAAcK using Electrospray-ionisation-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). Determined mass = 18947.80 g/mol, expected mass= 18948.43 g/mol. Effect of acetylation on cyclosporine binding. Fluorescence titration of Cs into CypA either non-acetylated (a) or acetylated (b). Acetylation reduces binding by approximately 20-fold. Plots represent a single titration in which each data point is the average of 20 measurements. Error bars represent mean values ± s.d. Quoted affinities represent the mean of three experiments ± s.d. Enzyme inhibition of CypA by Cs. CypA (a) and CypAcK (b) was preincubated with increasing concentrations of Cs and the remaining isomerase activity determined. An inhibition constant Ki of 1.3 ± 0.2 nM for CypA and an inhibition of 27 ± 5.6 nM for acetylated CypA can be calculated from the data. Acetylation modulates calcineurin inhibition. Comparison of the ability of Cs complexed with non-acetylated (a) or acetylated (b) CypA to inhibit calcineurin phosphatase activity. Acetylation reduces inhibition by 2-fold. The quoted inhibition constants (K i ) represent the average of duplicate experiments. Error bars represent mean values of three measurements ± s.d. Representative electron density for solved structures. Stereo figures for each determined structure showing the electron density and the protein backbone. (a) CypAcK (trigonal), (b) CypAcK (orthogonal), (c) HIV-1 and (d) CypAAcK from CypAAcK:HIV1 CA N and (e) CypAAcK:Cs-complex. Density maps were scaled at 1σ.Supplementary

TABREF0.text: used the standard EDTA-CaCl 2 sample tests as described by MicroCal to assess the statistical significance of individual observations. These gave values within the manufacturerʼs tolerances of ±20% for K a values and ±10% in ΔH.
